column1: Indio is a city in Riverside County
column2: California
column3: United States
column4: located in the Coachella Valley of Southern California's Colorado Desert region. It lies 23 miles (37 km) east of Palm Springs
column6: 127 miles (204 km) east of Los Angeles
column7: 148 miles (238 km) northeast of San Diego
column8: and 250 miles (402 km) west of Phoenix. The word Indio is Spanish for Indian.

column1: The population was 76
column2: 036 in the 2010 United States Census
column3: up from 49
column4: 116 at the 2000 census
column5: an increase of 55%. Indio was formerly referred to as the Hub of the Valley
column6: a Chamber of Commerce slogan used in the 1970s. It later was nicknamed the City of Festivals
column7: a reference to the numerous cultural events held in the city
column8: most notably the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

column1: == History ==
Railroad line construction east out of Los Angeles began in 1873. Trains were operated to Colton on July 16
column3: and to Indio (then Indian Wells) on May 29
column4: 1876. Moving on eastward from Indio
column5: the railroad reached the west bank of the Colorado River opposite Yuma on May 23
column6: 1877 (a village known as Arizona City prior to 1873). There was delay in getting military authority to lay tracks across the Yuma Indian reservation
column7: and it was September that year before the bridge was completed so trains could operate into Yuma. The Southern Pacific Railroad was to have joined those of the Texas & Pacific
column8: one of several railroads then holding
column9: or seeking
column10: federal authority to build lines from various sections of the country west to the Pacific Coast. But the rail-head of the T & P was at a standstill far off in Texas
column11: so Southern Pacific continued building eastward.The City of Indio came about because of the need of a halfway point for the Southern Pacific Railroad between Yuma
column13: since the engines needed to be refilled with water. At first
column14: the would-be city was called Indian Wells
column15: but since many other areas already had that name
column16: Indio (after a Spanish variation of the word "Indian") was chosen instead. After the railroad's arrival in 1876
column17: Indio really started to grow. The first permanent building was the craftsman-style Southern Pacific Depot station and hotel. Southern Pacific tried to make life as comfortable as it could for their workers in order to keep them from leaving such a difficult area to live in at the time. It was at the center of all social life in the desert with a fancy dining room and hosting dances on Friday nights.While Indio started as a railroad town
column21: citrus and dates thrived in the arid climate due to the ingenuity of farmers finding various means of attaining water
column22: first through artesian wells and later through the valley's branch of the All-American Canal. However
column23: water also was a major problem for Indio and the city was flooded several times until the storm water canals were created throughout the Coachella Valley.Businessmen and women found this last frontier land of the continental United States as an ideal place to start fresh. Dr. Harry Smiley and his wife Nell were early residents and stayed in Indio after their car broke down on the way to Los Angeles and became people of influence and helped shape the area. A. G. Tingman was an early store owner and first Postmaster of Indio
column24: but also well known for taking advantage of miners as they headed to the mountains
column25: selling at rather high prices. Later Dr. June Robertson McCarroll became a leading philanthropist and successful doctor in Indio. She was responsible along with the Indio Woman's Club for pressuring California into adopting the placing of white lines down the streets after she was nearly hit one too many times by passing vehicles. Even though these early founders of the city are considered pioneers
column26: they still partook in the lifestyles of their friends living in such areas as Los Angeles. Indio established itself quickly and kept up with the trends as they were brought in by the railroads.By the turn of the 20th century
column27: Indio was already more than a fading railroad town. Schools were built
column28: the La Casita hospital provided medical services
column30: about one to two thousand year-round residents lived in Indio
column33: 000 during the winter months and was advertised as a health resort for senior citizens and those with respiratory diseases and ailments in the rest of the 20th century.Indio also served as the home of the USDA's Date Station
column34: a place where leading scientific research was taking place on the fruit that would become a major part of the culture of Indio. The station started in 1907 and was responsible for the ability of local farmers to better understand this unique crop and make the Coachella Valley a leader in American date crops. This also created a tie to the Middle East that led to the theme for the County Fair with the Middle Eastern flair.Coachella and Thermal soon became larger cities than Indio
column35: but Indio remained the "Hub of the Valley"
column36: as it was called. With the burning of the majority of Thermal and the decline of Coachella
column38: Indio was a thriving area and incorporated. On September 6
column40: storekeeper Fred Kohler received the first business license in Indio.Indio was also aided by the visiting soldiers from Patton's training grounds in Chiriaco Summit located 30 miles to the east.In the second half of the 20th century
column41: Indio saw another decline as the valley's population begin to move west towards newer cities such as Palm Desert.  However
column42: there is now a reversal in this trend and the eastern section of the valley is poised to once again become the center of the Coachella Valley.

column1: == Geography ==

column2: −116.231889). According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 75.6 square kilometers (29 sq mi)
column4: 99.97% of which is land and 0.03% is water.

column1: The telephone area code is 760. The city's ZIP codes are 92201 and 92203 north of Interstate 10. About 3 miles (5 km) north and east of Indio is the San Andreas Fault
column2: a major tectonic plate boundary of the Pacific and North American plates.

column1: Indio is home of Riverside County's eastern administration offices. Palm Springs had more people from 1955 to 1992
column2: when the US census announced that Indio surpassed Palm Springs and that title was returned to them. The official elevation of Indio is below sea level; the city hall is 14 feet (4 m) below sea level
column3: as the eastern half of the Coachella valley drops as low as 150 feet (50 m) below sea level (the lakeshore of the Salton Sea is 15 miles (24 km) South of Indio).

column1: === Climate ===
The climate of the Coachella Valley is influenced by the surrounding geography. High mountain ranges on three sides contribute to its unique and year-round warm climate
column2: with some of warmest winters west of the Rocky Mountains. Indio has a warm winter/hot summer desert climate (Köppen: BWh): Its average annual high temperature is 89.5 °F (31.9 °C) and average annual low is 62.1 °F (16.7 °C) but summer highs above 108 °F (42 °C) are common and sometimes exceed 120 °F (49 °C)
column3: while summer night lows often stay above 82 °F (28 °C). Winters are warm with daytime highs often between 68–86 °F (20–30 °C). Under 4 inches (100 mm) of annual precipitation are average
column4: with over 348 days of sunshine per year. The hottest temperature ever recorded there was 125 °F (52 °C) on July 6

column1: === Nature and wildlife ===

Indio is in the Colorado Desert region of the Sonoran Desert. It is adjacent to the geologic Salton Sink and within the site of historic Lake Cahuilla of the Lower Colorado River Valley. Indio is an official National Bird Sanctuary
column2: because of the seasonal bird migration flight routes that cross the town en route to the Salton Sea.

column1: === Population growth ===
From 1984 to 2008
column2: Indio grew many times its previous size. Indio handles unprecedented growth for being a select area of choice for thousands of new residents per year. In 2018
column3: Indio was ranked the 30th fastest-growing city in America and 8th fastest-growing city in California.The 2010 United States Census recorded the city's population to be about 76
column4: 000 residents
column5: but it did not include the addition of seasonal residents. According to the Demographic Research Unit (DRU) of the California Department of Finance
column6: the provisional population estimate for the City of Indio as of January 1
column8: was 89
column9: 406.City leaders and other locals are expanding city public services

column1: == Economy ==
Two major contributions to the local economy are year-round agriculture and tourism
column2: although the majority of tourist activity is seasonal between October and May.

column1: === Agriculture ===
Indio has been one of Southern California's most important agricultural regions
column2: once responsible for a large percentage of the nation's date crop; however
column3: increasing residential and recreational development
column4: the date groves are now more limited to the south and southeast of Indio. Even the grove of date palm trees at the Riverside County Fair and national Date Festival grounds have been removed by the county.Travelers from around the world still can stop by Shields Date Gardens
column5: a date grower that maintains a large retail store along State Highway 111. There are citrus groves and vegetable fields surrounding the city limits
column6: but rapid development of new housing tracts and golf courses in the "East Valley" in the 1990s and 2000s has displaced most of the agricultural space.

column1: === Employment and job growth ===
In recent years
column2: Indio served as a magnet of job opportunities for immigrants and newcomers from parts of California and across the nation. Job fields such as agriculture
column3: construction
column4: hospitality (hotels and resorts)
column6: and retail and housekeeping are highly needed in the area.

column1: Construction and government are one of the largest employment sectors in Indio
column2: with a higher proportion of workers in these industries in Indio than the rest of the Coachella Valley.In addition to construction and government
column3: a recent 2019 study revealed that the top five employment industries in Indio are educational services
column4: entertainment services
column6: agriculture/mining/construction
column7: and waste services. Between 2007 and 2015
column8: the percentage of retail trade jobs in Indio increased by 4.4 percent and the percentage of education jobs increased from 15.2 to 20.5 percent.

column1: === Native American gaming ===
Two Native American owned casinos in and near Indio are the Fantasy Springs Resort Casino
column2: owned by the Cabazon Band of Mission Indians
column3: and the Spotlight 29 Casino
column4: owned by the Twenty-Nine Palms Band of Mission Indians. Spotlight 29 formerly was "Trump 29" when it was partly owned by then-businessman Donald Trump for a brief period of time in the 2000s.

column1: == Arts and culture ==
=== Annual events ===
Because of the numerous festivals and special events held annually in Indio
column2: the Chamber of Commerce deemed Indio's official nickname to be "The City of Festivals". The Date Festival/County Fairgrounds is a facility that hosts various events year round such as music concerts
column3: 4x4 monster truck rallies
column4: rodeos

column1: Two major annual festivals are the Riverside County Fair and National Date Festival and the Indio International Tamale Festival. Riverside County Fair and National Date Festival is held each February at the Riverside County Fairgrounds
column2: located on Highway 111 in the heart of Indio. Since 1947
column3: this festival has celebrated the date fruit crop of the Coachella Valley. The Tamale Festival is held each December on the streets of Old Town Indio and holds one Guinness World Record as the largest tamale festival (120
column4: 000 in attendance
column6: 2000) and once held the record for the world's largest tamale
column7: [over 1 foot (0.3 m) in diameter and 40 feet (12.2 m) in length]
column8: created by Chef John Sedlar
column9: but that record has since been surpassed.In 1993
column12: booked a Pearl Jam concert at the Empire Polo Club in Indio
column14: the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival was born. Since 2001
column15: Coachella has been an annual event that has brought notable music acts to the desert
column35: Roger Waters and several others. Coachella extended the festival to three days in 2007. Organizers eliminated single-day tickets in 2010 and went to three-day passes only. The festival continues to draw large numbers of concertgoers to Indio and the Empire Polo Club

column40: a three-day country music festival held the weekend following the Coachella. Performers have included George Strait

column3: with a golf course opening approximately every 100 days. During the winter months

column6: in particular

column1: === Indio's Old Town Historic Mural Program ===
In the fall of 1996
column2: the Indio Chamber of Commerce formed a committee to develop a Historic Mural Project to help revitalize the local economy at the time of the statewide economic recession. Several communities have benefited from similar programs
column3: such as Chemainus
column4: Canada; El Paso
column6: Bishop
column7: Needles
column8: & 29 Palms in California
column9: as well the famous Chicano Park mural to commemorate Hispanic-American life in Barrio Logan
column10: San Diego in the late 1970s.It began with a suggestion to start a mural project first brought to the city by David Hernandez
column11: a former Indio city council member
column12: after he visited Chemainus. Very little happened with this concept until 1996
column13: when the Riverside County National Date Festival's executive director Bruce Latta and commissioned artist Bill Weber of San Francisco to paint a mural of the Taj Mahal on the Taj Mahal (Garden of Allah) building at the fairgrounds. At the same time
column15: who was instrumental in promoting Historic U.S. Route 99 (Indio Blvd.) to its former status as the Main Street of California. He maintains a website on Historic Route 99 <https://web.archive.org/web/20140204023132/http://www.indiocaroute99.com/component/option
column17: 1/>. He brought the mural idea forward again after seeing the success of a similar local program in 29 Palms. When Clark presented the idea to the chamber board of directors
column18: the idea was immediately recognized as something that could help the city's economy by encouraging tourism. Indio now has ten murals about the city on the sides of various buildings in Old Town and on a water reservoir tank on Monroe Street.

column1: == Politics ==
In the California State Legislature
column2: Indio is in the  28th Senate District
column3: represented by Republican Melissa Melendez
column4: and in the  56th Assembly District
column5: represented by Democrat Eduardo Garcia.In the United States House of Representatives
column6: Indio is in California's  36th congressional district
column7: represented by Democrat Raul Ruiz.The City operates under a City Council-City Manager form of government with five elected members of the City Council served by a City Manager and staff and City Attorney. The five councilmembers are elected by district for four-year terms. Each year the Council selects the Mayor on a rotational basis and determines assignments for the external commissions and committees at its first meeting of December. The City Council is the legislative body for the City
column8: Public Financing Authority and Redevelopment Agency. Its responsibilities include establishing City policies
column9: adopting of ordinances and resolutions as well as the budget
column12: and the appointment of the City Manager
column13: City Attorney and the member of City commissions and committees.

College of the Desert
column2: commonly referred to by its initials (C.O.D)

The California Desert Trial Academy College of Law was approved by the California State Bar as an unaccredited fixed facility law school in Indio and is currently holding classes in the County Law Library in Indio. Meanwhile

column1: == Media ==
The Indio Date Palm was an early paper established in 1912 by John Winfield (J. Win) Wilson.Print news in Indio is most notably provided by The Desert Sun
column2: a daily newspaper part of the USA Today Network with a circulation of 14
column3: 685 in Indio in 2017. Providing news coverage of the Coachella Valley and distributing to eight cities
column4: The Desert Sun had the largest newspaper circulation in the desert in 2017.

column1: The Coachella Valley also receives news coverage from the Press-Enterprise
column2: a Riverside-based daily newspaper
column3: and Desert Star Weekly
column4: a Riverside County adjudicated newspaper. There are many other independently or self published daily newspapers and weeklies covering Indio
column5: such as the Coachella Valley Independent and Tidbits of the Coachella Valley.

column1: Newspapers aimed at a Latino readership are also essential in Indio
column2: due to the high number of Spanish-speaking Hispanics/Latinos in the area. El Informador del Valle is printed in Spanish then distributed to homes and a range of meat markets
column3: gas stations
column4: Hispanic restaurants
column5: and more locally owned businesses throughout Indio. La Prensa Hispana is another such newspaper that is aimed toward Indio's Latino community
column6: but uniquely merges English and Spanish together to provide a bilingual newspaper. The newspaper has received recognition from the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce-Coachella Valley for its value and impact on the community.There are also several online news sources that cover Indio
column7: such as the Coachella Valley Weekly
column8: Cactus Hugs
column9: Coachella Magazine
column11: and Los Angeles Times. Entertainment and lifestyle magazines and publications include the Desert Entertainer

column1: Indio has ten local television stations serving the Coachella Valley and six Spanish-language networks (local or regional affiliates like KUNA-LP and KVER-CD)
column2: some of which are over-air signals from Mexico. Eight Los Angeles television stations are available on cable and satellite service.

column1: Four out of 20 Palm Springs area's radio stations are licensed to Indio: KESQ 1400 AM (in Spanish) owned by KESQ-TV/KDFX-CD
column2: KKUU 92.7 FM (Urban/Hip-hop/R&B) owned by Morris Communications
column3: KHCV 104.3
column4: and classic rock KRHQ 102.3 FM owned by RM Broadcasting. However
column5: none of the stations have their offices or studios in Indio. KHCV and KESQ are located in Palm Desert; both KKUU and KRHQ are located in Palm Springs.

column1: == Public safety ==
Indio has its own police department. In 2016
column2: the Indio Police Department was one among 15 law enforcement agencies chosen to participate in President Barack Obama's 21st Century Policing Task Force. Recognized for its achievements in community engagement
column3: the Indio Police Department was charged with implementing the Task Force's recommendations for policing in a year-long study. During Coachella Fest
column4: Indio Police is able to handle a large number of 911 and non-emergency calls due to its six-position public safety answering point (PSAP).In addition to the Indio Police Department
column5: the city also contracts with the Riverside County Sheriff's Department for police services.The city of Indio contracts for fire and paramedic services with the Riverside County Fire Department through a cooperative agreement with CAL FIRE. Indio has 4 fire stations utilized to reduce response times
column6: and a full-time staff of 56 people.The City of Indio also has a Fire Services Prevention Office
column7: and
column8: through the Riverside County
column9: participates in the Volunteer Reserve Firefighter Program.One of the eleven U.S. Customs and Border Protection stations is located in Indio. Created in 1936
column10: the station was originally an auxiliary for the El Centro Sector station. Now
column11: the border patrol agents stationed in Indio are tasked with patrolling the northern portion of Imperial County.Indio is also the site of a California Highway Patrol Border Division office. The division patrols Interstate 10
column15: which encompasses cities such as Desert Hot Springs

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Transportation ===
Bermuda Dunes Airport (FAA designator: UDD) is on the north-western border of Indio
column2: along I-10 just west of Jefferson Street. It has a 5
column3: 000-foot (1
column4: 500 m) runway and serves small private planes
column5: air carriers and commuter jets. The Jacqueline Cochran Regional Airport in Thermal just a few minutes from Indio
column6: is named for the famous 1920s pilot and Indio resident and used for cargo planes to ship agricultural products
column7: also on the four-lane California State Route 86 expressway or the "NAFTA highway" (in reference to the North American Free Trade Agreement) for international traffic. The closest airport with regularly-scheduled commercial passenger service is Palm Springs International Airport
column8: about 20 miles (32 km) away.

column1: Greyhound and Amtrak Thruway Motorcoach intercity passenger buses stop at Indio  station with regular services to stops in Southern California
column2: Arizona
column3: and the Mexican border. The city is served by the local bus line SunLine Transit Agency ("SunBus")
column4: which services much of the Coachella Valley. The Amtrak rail station is expected to be reactivated in April 2021 for that year's Coachella Valley Music Festival. As of 2020 the city and the Riverside County Transportation Commission are planning a passenger rail service that will run to Los Angeles from Indio.

column1: Interstate 10 is the primary highway in the city
column2: running roughly on the north side. Highway 111 runs through the city which connects the northern end with I-10 in Whitewater
column3: CA to the southern end in Calexico
column4: California.

column1: === Health care ===
The city has a major hospital providing general acute care
column2: known as the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital. JFK Memorial Hospital provides a range of services
column3: from 24/7 emergency care to surgical services. One of three hospitals in the Coachella Valley
column4: JFK hospital expanded and opened a new maternity center as part of a 2002 hospital expansion plan for more surgical rooms
column5: intensive care units and a new concrete emergency heliport. The Indio (renamed John F. Kennedy) hospital opened in a new location in 1983 on land donated by hospital co-founder Dr. Reynaldo J. Carreon.In 2017
column6: JFK Memorial Hospital
column7: Desert Regional Medical Center
column8: and Hi-Desert Medical Center
column9: along with several affiliated outpatient clinics and centers
column10: came together to form the Desert Care Network. According to Desert Care Network CEO Michelle Finney
column11: the main purpose of the Desert Care Network is to "help improve care coordination between our hospitals and our affiliated entities for the more than 125
column12: 000 patients we treat every year."Indio and the rest of the Coachella Valley recognize the need for free or affordable health care services for its residents. Coachella Valley Volunteers in Medicine
column13: a branch of Volunteers in Medicine
column14: is the Coachella Valley's only no-cost clinic providing chronic

column1: acute
column2: preventive
column3: and mental health care to adult residents. Located in Indio
column4: the clinic had a total of 3
column6: California Care Force
column7: a non-profit organization that sets up temporary no-cost clinics across California
column8: provides free medical
column9: dental
column10: and vision services for residents at the Riverside County Fairgrounds in Indio each year. In its seventh annual free clinic in 2019
column12: 818 Coachella Valley uninsured and underinsured residents.In 2018
column13: Loma Linda University Children's Health - Indio opened its doors to serve approximately 150 children per week on a range of pediatric services such as general pediatric care
column15: and behavioral health counseling. The clinic's large scope of health care services and weekly number of patients is largely due to its 13
column16: 000 square feet size—making it the largest pediatric center in the Coachella Valley.

column1: === Parks and recreation ===
The city of Indio operates a variety of public parks
column2: including a municipal golf course
column3: a community recreation center
column4: a senior center one block from the Indio teen center located across from Indio High school
column5: and the Desert Park Wildlife Refuge north of 40th and 42nd Avenues.
